choices.text: pig
choices.explanation: Incorrect. A pig is an animal.

choices.text: doll
choices.explanation: Correct. A doll is a toy, not an animal.

choices.text: bird
choices.explanation: Incorrect. A bird is an animal.

choices.text: dog
choices.explanation: Incorrect. A dog is an animal.

choices.text: circle
choices.explanation: Correct. A circle is round in shape.

choices.text: square
choices.explanation: Incorrect. A square has four sides and corners.

choices.text: corner
choices.explanation: Incorrect. A corner is not round.

choices.text: pass
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Pass' is a verb, not an object.

questions.text: I like to ______ my room to make it look pretty.

choices.text: delicious
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Delicious' describes taste.

choices.text: frozen
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Frozen' means very cold.

choices.text: decorate
choices.explanation: Correct. 'Decorate' means make something look nice.

choices.text: confident
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Confident' describes a person, not a room.

questions.text: If you try to walk on an icy pond you may ______.

choices.text: lean
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Lean' means bend your body.

choices.text: confess
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Confess' means admit something.

choices.text: slide
choices.explanation: Correct. On ice, you may slide.

choices.text: submit
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Submit' means hand in or yield.

choices.text: hostile
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Hostile' means unfriendly.

choices.text: rehearse
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Rehearse' is a verb, not adjective.

choices.text: problematic
choices.explanation: Correct. A problematic idea causes difficulties.

choices.text: scarce
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Scarce' means rare, not describing an idea.

questions.text: Harry is 9. Judy is 12. Bill is 15. Which statement is true?

choices.text: Bill is the older.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Should be 'the oldest'.

choices.text: Harry is more young than Judy.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong comparative form.

choices.text: Judy is oldest to Harry.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong structure.

choices.text: Bill is older than Harry.
choices.explanation: Correct. 15 > 9.

questions.text: John hurt himself on a hike.

choices.text: He is walking a long time before he hurt himself.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Tense mismatch.

choices.text: He has been walked a long time before he hurt himself.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong passive form.

choices.text: He had been walking a long time before he hurt himself.
choices.explanation: Correct. Past perfect continuous describes duration before another past action.

choices.text: He has been walking a long time before he hurt himself.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Should be past perfect continuous.

questions.text: I started my job two months ago and still work in the same place. Which sentence has a similar meaning?

choices.text: I am working at my job for two months.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Present continuous doesn’t express duration.

choices.text: I had been working at my job for two months.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to a past event before another past event.

choices.text: I have been working at my job for two months.
choices.explanation: Correct. Present perfect continuous expresses an action started in the past and continuing now.

choices.text: I was working at my job for two months.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Refers to a past period only.

questions.text: Sue is 1.6 m. Henry is 1.7 m. Paul is 1.8 m. Which statement is true?

choices.text: Paul is more taller than Sue.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'More taller' is double comparative.

choices.text: Sue is the shortest.
choices.explanation: Correct. 1.6 m is less than 1.7 and 1.8.

choices.text: Henry is less tall to Paul.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong comparative form.

choices.text: Sue is the tall.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Should be 'the tallest'.

questions.text: What are your plans for next year?

choices.text: I will look for a new job.
choices.explanation: Correct. 'Will' shows future intention.

choices.text: I looking for a new job.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Missing 'am'.

choices.text: I am look for a new job.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong verb form.

choices.text: I maybe look for a new job.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Maybe' cannot modify a verb directly.

choices.text: The bus drove and a car was crashing into it.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Past continuous doesn’t fit after 'drove'.

choices.text: The bus drove and then a car crashed into it.
choices.explanation: Correct. Describes sequence of past actions clearly.

choices.text: The bus was driving and a car was crashing into it.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Both continuous forms sound unnatural together.

choices.text: The bus was driving when a car crashed into it.
choices.explanation: Also acceptable. Describes an interrupted action.

choices.text: If you will leave milk out, it will spoil.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'If' clause should not use 'will'.

choices.text: If you leave milk out, it spoils.
choices.explanation: Correct. Zero conditional expresses general truth.

choices.text: If you are leaving milk out, it is spoiling.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Awkward tense combination.

choices.text: If you left milk out, it spoiled.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Past simple doesn’t express general rule.

questions.text: You are making plans for your vacation. Which is correct?

choices.text: If I will be tired, I would go to the beach.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Wrong combination of 'will' and 'would'.

choices.text: If I have enough courage, I will go climbing.
choices.explanation: Correct. First conditional: present + future form.

choices.text: If I will have enough money, I will go far away.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. 'Will' is not used in 'if' clause.

choices.text: If I have a lot of time, I take a long trip.
choices.explanation: Incorrect. Missing future form in result clause.
